question: The embryo becomes a fetus by the end of which week of pregnancy?
rationale: The correct answer is option B. 8 (pg 883). The prenatal period involves the development of the embryo and fetus. After implantation when the egg divides, it is known as the embryo. Rapid growth occurs and by the end of 8 weeks the embryo can be recognized as human and is referred to as a fetus.

question: Which of the following is an important milestone that occurs around 16–20 wks of pregnancy?

choices.option0: A. Beginning of the sucking reflex
choices.option2: C. Development of layers in the cerebral cortex

rationale: The correct answer is option B. Detection of fetal movement (p 883–884). Women usually detect fetal movements between 16–20 weeks into the pregnancy. Taste and smell development occur in the fetus around 7 months. The sucking reflex typically does not appear until 28 weeks. The cerebral cortex layers typically don’t appear until the 6 month of pregnancy.

question: How does the developing fetal brain compare to the adult brain?

choices.option1: B. Cerebral cortex layers are more numerous
choices.option2: C. Increased number of neuronal connections occur
choices.option4: E. White matter is less sensitive to injur

rationale: The correct answer is option D. More neurons are generated (pg 884–885). The fetus develops more neurons that it needs for adult life and pruning occurs to get rid of these neurons and apoptosis, or cell death occurs. White mater in the fetal brain, especially before 22 weeks, is more sensitive to damage, such as from hypoxia. At birth the number of new neurons is negligible, and the branching of dendrites and new connections will occur afterwards. The cerebral cortex does not begin to form layers until the 6 month of pregnancy.

question: An OB brought up concerns of fetal growth delay and the mother was referred for a fetal echo and cardiac concerns were noted. At birth, exam of the infant is noted for small eyeballs, underdevelopment of the mid face and a thin upper lip, along with a large distance between the eyes. Which psychiatric disorder is this patient most likely at risk for later in childhood and adolescence?
rationale: The correct answer is option A. Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (pg 886). The infant above has symptoms characteristic of fetal alcohol syndrome. It affects about 1/3 of infants born to alcoholic women and symptoms include growth retardation and dysmorphic faces with microcephaly, hypertelorism large distance between the eyes), microphthalmia (small eyeblals0, short palpebral fissures, inner epicanthal folds, short palpebral fissures, short philtrum, thin upper lip, short, upturned notes, etc. Cardiac defects and CNS manifestations, including seizures, are often present. Other psychiatric symptoms or CNS manifestations include hyperactivity, attention deficit, and learning and intellectual disabilities.

question: Which reflex does not disappear until the 12th month of life?
rationale: The correct answer is option D. Plantar (Babinski) (pg 887). Reflexes present at birth including rooting, grasp reflex, the plantar (Babinski), the knee and abdominal reflexes and the startle (Moro) reflex along with the tonic neck reflex. In healthy children, by 4 months old the grasp, startle, and tonic neck reflex disappear.  It takes until 12 moths for the Babinski reflex to disappear.

question: Which is the most common cause of malformations in the first year of life?
rationale: The correct answer is option A. Autosomal genetic diseases (pg 887). Autosomal genetic diseases are thought to account for most of the malformations in the first year of life (15–20%). Cytogenetic or chromosomal abnormalities are thought to account for 5%. Maternal endocrine conditions (4%), maternal infections (3%), and chemicals, drug, radiation, hyperthermia, and preconception exposures (<1%)  are less common causes.

question: A mother expresses frustration that her 2–year–old cannot put on her shoes and struggles with feeding herself. During play she can only build a tower of a few cubes and says  "no " to her mother often and struggles with taking turns. Which of the following is the net most appropriate intervention by the psychiatrist?

choices.option0: A. Arrange more playdates to focus on turn taking and playing with other children
choices.option1: B. Have the child evaluated by early intervention services
choices.option2: C. Reassurance that these behaviors are normal for her age and in another year most of those milestones should be met
choices.option3: D. Recommend a private occupational therapy evaluation
choices.option4: E. Refer for parent management training to help the mother set up a behavioral chart to reinforce positive action

rationale: The correct answer is option C. Reassurance that these behaviors are normal for her age and in another year most of those milestones should be met (pg 888). At 2 years old, a toddler should be able to pull on simple clothing items and say  "no " to their mother. Parallel play, in which they play side by side without interacting with other children is normal for this age. Typically, a 2 year old can build a tower of 6 or 7 cubes. By 3 years old a child should be able to do the other things mentioned in the vignette such as put on shoes, feed themselves well, understand taking turns, and build a tower of more blocks (9 or 10) cubes.

question: An adult is making silly faces and tickling an infant. At which age should the infant be able to smile back?
rationale: The correct answer is option C. 4 months (pg 888). While an endogenous smile can be noted at birth, the spontaneous social smile, or exogenous smile, does not typically occur unit around 4 weeks of life.

question: At what maximum age should a child be able understand complex sentences, pronouns, put two–words together when speaking, and though not fully understandable, start to use 3 words together while speaking?
rationale: The correct answer is option C. 2 years old (pg 889). A 2–year–old should be able to put two words together for a simple utterance and start to use 3–word telegraphic utterances, with only around half being intelligible. A 2 year old should also be also refer to themselves by name.

question: A child is detail oriented, very focused, and recently learned how to play checkers well. The child can understand that when his ice cubs melts, the same amount of liquid is still present. Which developmental period has this child entered?
rationale: The correct answer is option C. Concrete operational (pg 890). The Four Piaget states of cognitive development include the sensorimotor stage (birth –2 years old), preoperational (2–7yo), concrete operational (7–11yo), and formal operational (11–19yo). Pre–production is a stage of language, not cognitive development.  Cognitive achievements in the concrete stage are highlighted above, including principles of reversibility (i.e. can play games backwards and forwards), conservation (i.e. can understand conservation of matter), and decentration (i.e. worrying about small details).

question: What is the earliest age that infants can imitate facial movements of adult caregivers?
rationale: The correct answer is option B. 3 weeks (pg 890). By as young as 3 weeks old, infants can imitate facial movements of adult caregivers. They can open their mouths and thrust their tongues when adults do the same. By the 3rd and 4th months this behavior is easily elicited, and the exogenous social smile occurs.

question: A 1–2–year–old is most likely to display which of the following emotional behaviors?
rationale: The correct answer is option B. Approval seeking (pg 891). In terms of emotional development, in early childhood (3–6 years old) a child can display empathy, and aggression turns into competition at this age. Self–regulation begins to occur, and children become less reactive. By 5 years old children typically show sensitivity to criticism and care about the feelings of others. By middle childhood (7–11 years old) altruism can be displaced and the superego dominates. At 1–2 years old, some indications of empathy are starting, though attention seeking and the need for approval predominate.

question: Which is a distinguishing factors between stranger anxiety versus separation anxiety?

choices.option1: B. Developmental ability to distinguish caregiver from others
choices.option3: D. Occurrence when the infant is still in the mother’s armsg
choices.option4: E. It starts later in infanc

rationale: The correct aner is oping D. Occurrence when the infant is still in the mother’s arms (pg 892). Stranger anxiety is a developmentally normal fear that starts around 26 weeks of life, whereas separation anxiety typically begins later around 10–18 months. When babies are approached by strangers they cry and cling ot their mother. Babies with only one caregiver are more likely to have stranger anxiety. Stranger anxiety occurs when the infant is in the mother’s arms, whereas with separation anxiety, the anxiety occurs when the person the infant is attached to separates.

question: A toddler looks back at his mother before going ahead and touching a dog in a park. This is an example of which of the following developmental concepts?
rationale: The correct answer is option D. Social referencing (pg 893).  Social referencing, typically occurring around 2 years of age, is when the child looks towards the parents and others for emotional cues as to how to respond to novel events. The child must have object permanence to be able to social refence. Transitional objects (as coined by Donald Winnicott), such as a teddy bear for example, can offer a secure base and as a child investigates the world around them. With secure attachment, children are better adjusted with few problems and receive more consistent and developmentally appropriate parenting. Insecure attachment can be avoidant, such as children being anxious, clings and angry with the parent, or ambivalent, with disorganized, and neglectful parents.

question: Gender identity is thought to be fixed by which of the following age ranges?
rationale: The correct answer is option B. 2–2.5yo (pg 894). It used to be thought that gender identity, the conviction of being male or female, was a function of social learning. It is now known that rearing does not affect gender identity. Gender identity begins to manifest at 18 months and is typically fixed by 24–30 months old.

question: Which is a common factor to children who experience imaginary companions?

choices.option3: D. Occurrence most commonly during school age years

rationale: The correct answer is option B. High intelligence (pg 895). Imaginary companions most commonly occur in the preschool years and are typically found in those with high intelligence. Typically, they disappear by age 12yo and occur in up to 50% of children. Though the significance is not clear, it is thought to reduce anxiety and the companions are typically described as friendly figures.

question: What is the typical focus on in development of children in the middle years?

choices.option1: B. Idealizing the opposite sex parent
choices.option2: C. Interest in relations outside of the family

rationale: The correct answer is option C. Interest in relations outside of the family (pg 895). During the middle years, age 6 to puberty, peer interactions assume significant importance. Interest in relationships outside of the family predominate during the middle years and the children form a special relationship with the same sex parent and view them as a role model. Peer rivalry and struggles with aggressive impulses and taking turns typically occurs in the preschool years. Distinguishing reality from fantasy and focusing on play is also characteristic of the preschool, not the middle years. The middle years typically were thought of as the latency period, including exploration of sexual play. It is now known that a considerable amount of sexual interest does occur throughout these years.

question: Which is characteristic of normal dreams for a 6 year–old?

choices.option1: B. Belief that they are real
choices.option2: C. Occurrence during stage 4 of sleep
choices.option3: D. Thinking they are shared by more than one person
choices.option4: E. Visions of being killed or injured

rationale: The correct answer is option E. Visions of being killed or injured (pg 896). By 5 or 6yo children often dream of being killed or injured, fear of flying, being in cars, or of ghosts. At 5yo children realize their dreams are not real. At 3yo children believe their dreams are shared by more than one person. Sleep disorders, such as parasomnias and enuresis or bedwetting, though common are not part of normal dreaming and actually occur during state 4 sleep when dreaming is minimal.

question: Children of divorced families have higher rates of which medical or psychiatrist symptom?
rationale: The correct answer is option E. Suicide (pg 897). Children of divorced families have much higher suicide rates compared to intact families. Antisocial personality disorder, conduct disorder and ADHD are more common in children in homes with absent fathers. Children from divorced homes have more struggles with academic achievement and social relations and are more withdrawn, lonely, anxious, and insecure. Aggression, especially onset boys is common. They also have higher rates of medical issues including injury, asthma, and headaches.

question: Aside from perception as having a high value to peers and family, which other factor is the most important correlate of having good self–esteem?

choices.option2: C. High number of social media followers
choices.option3: D. Perception of attractive physical appearance

rationale: The correct answer is option D. Perception of attractive physical appearance (pg 902). The most important correlates of a good self–esteem, a measure o one’s sense of self–worth, has been shown to be one’s perception of attractive physical appearance and high value to peers and family. Secondary features include academic achievement, athletic ability, and unique talents. Positive feedback form peers also contribute to self–esteem. In general, girls have more issues maintaining a positive self–esteem than boys do.

question: After accidents, which of the following factors is the 2nd leading cause of death amongst people aged 15 to 25 years old?
rationale: The correct answer is option C. Homicides (pg. 903). Violent crimes by young offenders are on the increase in the US. Homicides are the 2nd leading cause of death among people aged 15 to 25 years old, with accidents being the first cause, and suicide the 3rd.

question: Which is an imminent warning sign of impending school violence?

choices.option2: C. Serious physical fights with peers or family

rationale: The correct answer is option C. Serious physical fights with peers or family members (pg 904). According to CDC, in 2010, approximately 2 percent of deaths occurred due to school violence. Imminent warning signs include serious physical fights with peers or family, severe destruction of property, serious rage, detailed threats of violence, poison, or firearms. Early warning signs include feelings of isolation or withdrawal, rejection, being a victim of violence, having a history of discipline problems, drug and EtOH use, gang affiliation, and threats of violence.

question: A patient has been struggling with isolation, and is unable to help others, and contribute to society. Which developmental sage is the patient struggling with and at what stage of life is this typically found at?

choices.option0: A. Generativity vs stagnation; early adulthood
choices.option1: B. Generativity vs stagnation; middle adulthood
choices.option2: C. Identity formation vs diffusion; late adolescence
choices.option3: D. Integrity vs despair; late adulthood
choices.option4: E. Integrity vs. despair, middle adulthood

rationale: The correct answer is option B. Generativity versus stagnation; middle adulthood (pg 909). Erikson descried middle adulthood (40–65yo) as being characterized by generativity or stagnation. The person can help guide future generations and improve society by helping others, being reactive, etc. or they can end up being stagnant and stop developing. They can end up feeling isolated and focusing on themselves and struggle more with old age.  Integrity vs despair occurs in old age and involves the process of reviewing one’s life and coming to a sense of peace with how one’s life was lived and struggling to do so can cause despair. For adolescents the tasks is identity formation vs diffusion, starting late adolescence, continuing to early adulthood.  It involves defining their sense of self, belonging, hobbies, etc. and continuing to refine their identity.

question: Which is a neuropsychiatric change associated with aging?

choices.option1: B. Learning takes longer, but still occurs
choices.option2: C. Recognition of right answer on multiple choice tests declines
choices.option3: D. Transfer of information from short to long–term memory increases

rationale: The correct answer is option B. Learning takes longer, but still occurs (pg 915). Neuropsychiatric changes with aging include it taking longer to learn new material but learning new information can still occur. IQ remains stable until 80 years old. Verbal ability is maintained with age in terms of memory, though encoding ability diminishes (i.e., transfer of short to long–term memory and vice vera). Simple recall declines, though recognition of right answers on multiple choice testes remain intact with aging.

question: Which of the following is true regarding the tumor depicted in Figure 1?

choices.option0: A. Early and frequent lymph node metastasis
choices.option1: B. Highest prevalence in the parotid gland
choices.option3: D. Rarely recurs after surgical intervention
choices.option4: E. Slow growing and indolent neoplasm

rationale: Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) accounts for approximately 10% of all salivary gland tumors, and it is the most common malignant tumor of the submandibular and minor salivary glands. There are three patterns of growth and multiple patterns are often seen in the same tumor. The cribriform pattern is the most common, with microcysts filled with basement membrane–like material surrounded by uniform cuboidal cells, as well as true mucus-filled glandular spaces. The combination of cystic and glandular spaces is required for diagnosis. The tubular pattern is seen in 20% to 30% of cases and is characterized by smaller ductlike arrays of basaloid epithelial cells surrounding a single central lumen-like space with fibrotic/hyalinized stroma. The solid pattern is the least frequently encountered and characterized by solid nests of basaloid cells, often in a hyalinized stroma. The tubular ACC can be confused with polymorphous adenocarcinoma (PAC), an indolent neoplasm. Immunohistochemically, ACC shows two distinct cell populations: myoepithelial cells that are positive for p40, p63, and S-100 protein, and ducts that are negative for those markers. In comparison, PAC is diffusely positive for S-100 protein and consistently positive for p63 but negative for p40.  Perineural invasion is a constant feature, resulting in tumor spread well beyond the surgical margins: this accounts for recurrences 10 to 20 years following resection, with resultant poor long-term prognosis. Although ACC may involve lymph nodes by direct extension, direct lymph node lymph node metastases are rare. Approximately 40% to 70% of adenoid cystic carcinomas exhibit a t(6;9) translocation, resulting in an MYB-NFIB gene fusion, whereas 10% to 20% harbor MYBL1-NFIB.

question: What is the most common molecular alteration seen in the entity from question 12?
rationale: Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) accounts for approximately 10% of all salivary gland tumors, and it is the most common malignant tumor of the submandibular and minor salivary glands. There are three patterns of growth and multiple patterns are often seen in the same tumor. The cribriform pattern is the most common, with microcysts filled with basement membrane–like material surrounded by uniform cuboidal cells, as well as true mucus-filled glandular spaces. The combination of cystic and glandular spaces is required for diagnosis. The tubular pattern is seen in 20% to 30% of cases and is characterized by smaller ductlike arrays of basaloid epithelial cells surrounding a single central lumen-like space with fibrotic/hyalinized stroma. The solid pattern is the least frequently encountered and characterized by solid nests of basaloid cells, often in a hyalinized stroma. The tubular ACC can be confused with polymorphous adenocarcinoma (PAC), an indolent neoplasm. Immunohistochemically, ACC shows two distinct cell populations: myoepithelial cells that are positive for p40, p63, and S-100 protein, and ducts that are negative for those markers. In comparison, PAC is diffusely positive for S-100 protein and consistently positive for p63 but negative for p40.  Perineural invasion is a constant feature, resulting in tumor spread well beyond the surgical margins: this accounts for recurrences 10 to 20 years following resection, with resultant poor long-term prognosis.
